metadata.title: A Hierarchically Porous Nickel-Copper Phosphide Nano-Foam for Efficient Electrochemical Splitting of Water

A Hierarchically Porous Nickel-Copper Phosphide Nano-Foam for Efficient Electrochemical Splitting of Water
Li Wei a , Kunli Goh b , Özgür Birer c , H. Enis Karahan b , Shengli Zhai a,b , Xuncai Chen a , and Yuan Chen a, *
Electrochemical splitting of water to produce oxygen (O2) and hydrogen (H2) through cathodic hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and anodic oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is a promising green energy supply approach. Here we demonstrated a porous nickel-copper phosphide (NiCuP) nano-foam as a bifunctional electrocatalyst for total water splitting. Prepared from a bubble-templated electrodeposition method and subsequent low-temperature phosphidization, NiCuP has a hierarchical pore structure with a large electrochemical active surface area. It requires merely 146 and 300 mV to reach a current density of 50 mA/cm2 and small Tafel slopes of 47 and 49 mV/dec for HER and OER, respectively. Total water splitting test using NiCuP as both anode and cathode showed nearly 100% Faradic efficiency and surpasses the performances of electrode pairs using commercial Pt/C and IrO2 catalysts in our test conditions. The high activity of NiCuP can be attributed to (1) the conductive NiCu substrates, (2) a large electrochemically active surface area together with a combination of pores in different sizes, and (3) the formation of active Ni/Cu oxides/hydroxides while keeping a portion of more conductive Ni/Cu phosphides in the nano-foam.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
To fulfil the growing energy needs, the production of H2 fuel (i.e. H2 gas) by the electrolytic splitting of water offers a great promise as a sustainable source of renewable energy. 1-3 Efficient realization of the H2 fuel production through the electrolytic splitting of water requires the employment of highperforming catalysts in both cathodic H2 evolution reaction (HER: 2H + + 2e – → H2) and anodic O2 evolution reaction (OER: 4OH – → O2 + 2H2O + 4e – ). 1, 4, 5 At present, Pt and IrO2 are considered as the state-of-the-art catalysts for HER and OER, respectively. 1, 6 However, being highly expensive and scarce hinder their practical use in water electrolysis. Wellengineered catalysts prepared using earth-abundant elements, such as Fe, Co, Ni and Cu, and their derivatives, come into prominence as affordable substitutes. 7, 8
Previous studies have showed that phosphides, 9-13
sulfides, 14-16 and selenides 17, 18 of earth-abundant metals can efficiently catalyze HER. On the other hand, Fe-Ni hydroxides, 19-22 Co polytungstates, 23, 24 and several metallic alloy oxide nanoparticles 25-33 are highly active for OER. Among catalysts containing earth-abundant elements, bifunctional catalysts are particularly attractive because they can catalyze
both HER and OER in the same medium, which brings them a competitive advantage in building water electrolysers with one integrated catalyst for both cathodic and anodic reactions. 34, 35 Recently, a number of HER catalysts including CoP, 36, 37 NiSe, 38 and NiPx 39 , were found to have good catalytic activity for OER as well. It is proposed that their OER activity originates from metal oxides, metal hydroxides or oxyhydroxides, produced either in catalysis synthesis or through in-situ transformation from phosphides or selenides. 35, 36, 39
In addition to catalyst chemical composition, several structural and physicochemical features of HER and OER catalysts are also critical for improving the efficiency of water electrolysers. 40, 41 First, maintaining a large surface-area-tovolume ratio helps to accommodate more catalytic active sites, leading to faster H2 or O2 generation. Second, achieving an optimum combination of pores in different sizes would allow faster mass transfer, facilitating the supply of fresh electrolytes and the elimination and/or departure of coalescent H2/O2 gas bubbles. Third, conductive catalyst supports/substrates enable the efficient charge transfer as many active catalysts have low electrical conductivity. 19, 21, 42 Considering these requirements, hierarchically porous three-dimensional metal foams have emerged as a promising platform to construct efficient electrodes for the electrolysis of water. 43, 44 Such structures provide an inherently interconnected metallic skeleton with multi-scale porosity, which not only enable fast transfers of electrons, electrolytes, and gas bubbles but also offer strong mechanical robustness for long-term water electrolysis under high current densities. It is desirable to integrate bifunctional HER and OER catalysts into such metal structures.

sections.heading: ARTICLE Journal Name
sections.text:
2 | J. Name., 2012, 00, 1-3 This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
Herein, we demonstrate a high-performance bifunctional catalyst by the phosphidization of a three-dimensional and hierarchically nano-foam of nickel (Ni) and copper (Cu) which we denote as NiCuP. We first created high surface area nanofoams of NiCu alloys on stainless steel foils by the electrodeposition method using H2 bubbles as templates instead of solid materials. 45 Next, we activated the surface of these bimetallic structures creating a catalytically more active metal phosphide layer. The resulting stainless steel foil electrodes coated with the active NiCuP catalyst were tested for both HER and OER. Their long-term performance stability under high current densities was also evaluated. Subsequently, solar cell powered water electrolyser was demonstrated using the NiCuP as both cathode and anode for electrolysis of water.

sections.heading: Results and discussion
sections.text:
The NiCuP electrodes were fabricated using the two-step method as illustrated in Figure 1a. In the first step, stainless steel foils were used as substrates for electrodeposition of the NiCu foam. In aqueous metal salt solutions, when cathodic overpotential reaches a sufficient level, H2 bubbles generated at the surface of electrodes will interrupt the metal deposition. This phenomenon, called the H2 bubble templated electrodeposition, has been explored as a novel method to create porous metal films. 45 It can circumvent the use of hard templates, such as polystyrene spheres, 46 surfactants 47 and anodic aluminium oxide, 48 and avoid subsequent template removal, also having the advantages of simplicity and scalability. During electrodeposition, if two metal ions are presented, bimetallic porous metal films can be generated. The bimetallic Ni and Cu nano-foams were used in this study for several reasons. First, Cu is one of the most efficient elements in forming metal deposits by this method. 49 Cu facilitates the formation of metal architectures much faster as compared to using Ni alone. Second, Ni and Cu oxides are both active catalysts for OER. 50, 51 NiCu alloys may lead to higher OER activity due to the synergistic effects between Ni and Cu. 6 Third, Ni and Cu phosphides are both active for HER. 9, 11 A recent study also found that Ni2P has a high activity for OER. 39 We expected that the phosphides of NiCu alloys might offer even higher HER and OER activities.
The deposition of NiCu was tested at various conditions, including different deposition time (30 to 180 sec), Ni concentrations (0.25 and 0.5 M), and Ni/Cu ratios (10, 25, 50 and 100). The optimized deposition was found at the current density of 1.8 A/cm 2 for 90 sec in 0.5 M NiSO4 and 0.01 M
CuSO4. At this condition, a large amount of H2 bubbles release from the surface of stainless steel foil and deposited NiCu alloys, which facilitates the formation of the hierarchically nano-foam (Figure S1a in the Electronic Supplementary Information (ESI) shows a photograph of the deposited NiCu of 0.5  1 cm 2 in size). After rinsing by DI water, the deposited NiCu was further anodized at 1.3 V (vs. reversible hydrogen electrode, RHE) in a 0.1 M NaOH solution for 30 sec. 52 Afterwards, it was exposed to a P precursor (NaH2PO2) at 300 °C for 60 min. The resulting stainless steel foil electrodes were loaded with 6.70 mg cm –2 of NiCuP catalysts (see Figure S1b in ESI for the photograph).
Figure 2. (a-b) SEM images of NiCuP catalysts at different resolutions. The inset of (a) shows the cross-section of the deposited catalyst layer on a stainless steel electrode (scale bar = 50 μm). (c) XRD patterns of deposited NiCu and NiCuP. (d) XPS survey scans and (e) high resolution XPS scans of P, Ni, and Cu of NiCu and NiCuP.
The morphology of NiCuP was first examined by scanning electron microscope (SEM). The SEM image given in Figure 2a shows the top view of a honeycomb structure resulting from the generation and dissipation of H2 bubbles during electrodeposition. Macropores of ~5-8 µm in diameter are uniformly distributed across the surface with the average pore wall thickness of ~2-4 µm. The thickness of the deposited layer is about 40 µm (inset of Figure 2a). Dendritic structure can be

sections.heading: Journal Name ARTICLE
sections.text:
This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx J. Name., 2013, 00, 1-3 | 3
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
observed in the high-resolution SEM image (Figure 2b), which provides nanosize channels as nanopores to generate hierarchical porosity. Liquid N2 physisorption also confirms the formation of nanopores with wide diameter distribution centered around 40 nm (Figure S2 in ESI). The hierarchical porosity of this NiCu foam offers a high specific area to accommodate more electrochemically active sites. This can be assessed by the electrode surface roughness factor (RF) derived from the ratio between the electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) and the geometric area of an electrode. Following an established method, 6 the ECSA of the NiCuP was estimated by measuring its electrical double-layer capacitance (Cdl), which is about 9.9 mF. Assuming a specific surface capacitance (Cs) of 40 µF/cm 2 , the RF value of the NiCuP is 494 (Figure S3 in ESI). This RF value is much larger than that of other electrodeposited Co-based catalysts reported so far. 35, 37 It is also nearly two orders greater than that of commercial Ni foams, which are widely used as metal substrates for electrode fabrication. 53 It should also be noted that the low temperature phosphidization treatment has minor impacts on the structure of NiCu foams. SEM images of NiCu in are similar to those of NiCuP in Figure 2a and 2b (Figure S4 in ESI). The RF of NiCu is 438, which is also similar to that of NiCuP. Moreover, the specific surface areas of NiCu and NiCuP measured by liquid N2 physisorption only differ by 5.4% (Figure S2 and discussion in ESI), confirming that negligible structure changes have happened during the phosphidization treatment.
The chemical structures of NiCuP were studied by various analysis techniques. Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) areal mapping results indicate that Ni, Cu, O, and P are uniformly distributed in NiCuP (Figure S5 in the Supplementary Material). The atomic ratio between Ni and Cu determined by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICPAES) is 1:0.56. Figure 2c shows X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of NiCu and NiCuP. The diffraction peaks can be assigned to copper phosphides and nickel phosphides on NiCuP according to the standard XRD patterns (Ni: PDF#04-0850, Cu: PDF#040836, Cu81Ni19 alloy: PDF#47-1406, NixP: PDF#03-0953 and CuxP: PDF#25-0302), confirming the formation of metal phosphides by NaH2PO2 treatment. 9, 11, 54 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) survey scans in Figure 2d show Ni, Cu, and O peaks on NiCu. After the NaH2PO2 treatment, the intensity of the O peak decreases significantly, while P peaks emerge. As seen in the high-resolution XPS scans given in Figure 2e, two types of P species are found in NiCuP. The peak at 129.8 eV belongs to P δ– in metal phosphides and the other peak at higher binding energy (133.1 eV) can be assigned to oxidized P species, such as metal phosphates (PO4 3– ). The XPS analyses of Ni and Cu are more complicated due to their complex chemical environments. As shown in Figure 2e, after NaH2PO2 activation, the peaks centered at 852.9 and 932.9 eV belong to Ni δ+ and Cu δ+ in metal phosphides. The other peaks with higher binding energies are resulted from Ni 2+ and Cu 2+ in the form of phosphates. Overall, XPS results show that the metal oxide layer on the surface of NiCu was transformed into a P rich layer. XPS depth profiles of the NiCuP were also recorded to gain a better understanding of P distribution in the catalyst.
Ar + bombardment is applied on the NiCuP electrode while high resolution XPS spectrum is collected every 20-second. The estimated thickness of the phosphide layer is around 6 nm (Figure S6 and discussion in ESI), 55 indicating that the phosphidization by the low temperature method used in study is limited to the very metal oxide surface layer of the NiCu.
Figure 3. (a-c) HER and (d-f) OER catalytic performances of NiCuP in 1 M KOH electrolyte. (a) HER polarization LSV scan curves, (b) Tafel plots, and (c) HER chronopotentiometric stability test. (d) OER polarization LSV scan curves, (e) Tafel plots, and (f) chronopotentiometric stability test and a multistep test from 50 to 500 mA/cm 2 with an increment of 50 mA/cm 2 per step. Stability tests are performed in a twochamber electrochemical cell separated with 4 mm glass grit without iR-compensation.
The catalytic performances of NiCuP for HER were first evaluated in H2-saturated 1 M KOH electrolyte in a threeelectrode configuration using a Pt gauze as the counter electrode. Figure 3a shows that NiCu has negligible activities for HER with high onset overpotential at –191 mV vs. reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). In contrast, NiCuP is highly active for HER with small onset overpotential of –42 mV. The potential required to reach a current density of 50 mA/cm 2 is only –146 mV. Cathodic H2 generation is clearly observed over the entire catalyst surface without rotating the electrode or agitating the electrolyte. The performance of NiCuP for HER was also compared with the commercial 20 wt.% Pt/C catalyst loaded on the carbon cloth electrode. With

sections.heading: ARTICLE Journal Name
sections.text:
4 | J. Name., 2012, 00, 1-3 This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
the rise of the overpotential, the cathodic current density of NiCuP shows a faster increase than that of Pt/C. Figure 3b shows that Pt/C has a linearly fitted Tafel slope of 97 mV/dec, indicating that the rate-limiting step of this Pt/C electrode transited from the Volmer step to the Heyrovsky step. The Tafel slope of NiCuP is merely 47 mV/dec, indicating that its rate-limiting step is approaching the Heyrovsky step. 56 This result shows that NiCuP is one of the best HER catalysts reported to date, comparable to Co phosphide/phosphate film (53 mV/dec), 37 Ni5P4 film (53 mV/dec), 57 and Co-P film under 2000 rpm stirring (42 mV/dec). 35 A detailed comparison of HER catalytic performances of recently reported bifunctional catalysts is listed in Table S1 in SI. A previous study reported that Ni phosphide has a lower stability in alkaline electrolyte used in HER. 11 The stability of NiCuP was evaluated at a current density of 50 mA/cm 2 for 120 h. As shown in Figure 3c, the required overpotential has only increased by ~8.9% after the 120 h electrolysis, indicating the excellent stability of NiCuP for HER.
Next, catalytic performances of NiCuP for OER were tested in O2-saturated 1 M KOH electrolyte. As shown in Figure 3d, there is a small peak at 1.43 V vs. RHE on the LSV scan curve of NiCuP, which can be attributed to the oxidation of Ni(II) to Ni(III) oxyhydroxide. 58 Further increase of the applied potential results in a more rapid increase in the current density, together with the release of a large amount of O2 bubbles in the electrolyte. The current density of 50, 100, and 500 mA/cm 2 was achieved at the overpotential of 300, 318, and 403 mV, respectively. A commercial IrO2 catalyst loaded on the carbon cloth electrode was measured under the same condition for performance comparison. The linearly fitted Tafel plots of NiCuP and IrO2 are shown in Figure 3e. The OER onset potential of NiCuP was 231 mV. This value is slightly higher than that of the state-of-the-art IrO2 at 130 mV. Importantly, NiCuP outperforms IrO2 when the applied potential is over 1.50 V. The fitted Tafel slope of NiCuP is 49 mV/dec, which is smaller than that of NiCuOx particles, 6 Ni-Cu alloy 58 and IrO2, indicating its superior OER performances. A detailed comparison of OER catalytic performances of recently reported bifunctional catalysts is listed in Table S2 in ESI.
The stability of NiCuP for OER was also tested in 1 M KOH electrolyte at 50 mA/cm 2 for 120 h. Figure 3f shows that the required overpotential only increases by ~9.4%, indicating excellent stability. In practical water electrolysers, OER is often limited by the mass transport of electrolytes and O2 bubbles. A multi-step chronopotentiometry response test was carried out to evaluate the mass transport properties of NiCuP under different current densities. The current density was amplified from 50 to 500 mA/cm 2 with 50 mA/cm 2 increment, and maintained at each current density for 300 sec. Figure 3f shows that NiCuP has both quick and stable responses at different current densities with negligible perturbations in its performance, suggesting its pore channels are not blocked by gas bubbles or disintegrated catalysts at the high current density. This can be attributed to its hierarchically porous architecture, good electrical conductivity, and mechanical robustness.
Ni and Cu phosphides or phosphates are usually not considered as active catalysts for OER. 7 It is therefore interesting to understand the origin of the high OER activity of NiCuP. Recently, Stern et al. proposed that metal phosphides and phosphates are partially converted to metal oxides and hydroxides in alkaline electrolytes, which contributes to the high OER activity of Ni phosphides. 39, 57 We hypothesized that a similar chemical conversion occurs in NiCuP that enables its high OER activity. To verify this hypothesis, we examined NiCuP after a 120-h OER test using SEM. Figure S7 in the ESI shows its surface structure changes. Surface elemental analysis by XPS (Figure S8 in ESI) indicates that the O content has significantly increased after OER test, while the ratio between Ni and Cu remains almost constant. These observations suggest that O has been incorporated into NiCuP during the OER test. The high-resolution XPS spectra (Figure S9 in the ESI) of Ni, Cu and O in NiCuP before and after the 120-h OER test were analyzed to elucidate its structure transformation. XPS spectra of Ni (Figure S9c) reveals that the intensity of Ni δ+ peak (at 852.9 eV) from Ni2P decreases significantly, while new peaks of Ni 3+ from NiOOH at 854.6, 856.8, and 861.1 eV emerge after the OER test. 59, 60 Similar changes are also observed in the XPS spectra of Cu (Figure S9d). These results support the hypothesis that Ni/Cu phosphides are partially converted into highly active Ni/Cu oxides/hydroxide. The potential drop further supports this conversion at the early stage (within 10 h) of the OER stability test (see Figure S10 in the Supplementary Material), indicating the increase of OER activity of NiCuP during the OER test.
Figure 4. (a) LSV curves and (b) OER Tafel plots of different electrode combinations. (c) The performance of the twoelectrode water electrolyser at 1.5 V and 1.6 V for 10 h. The inset shows the total charges passing the electrodes. (d) H2 and O2 produced during the electrolysis.
Since Ni/Cu oxides/hydroxides are important for the high catalytic activity. An intriguing question is what the roles of P

sections.heading: Journal Name ARTICLE
sections.text:
This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx J. Name., 2013, 00, 1-3 | 5
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
are. After passivation, a thin metal oxide layer covers the NiCu electrode (denoted as NiCuO). The OER performances of the anodic passivized NiCuO and NiCuP are compared. Their LSV polarization curves are shown in Figure S11 in SI. NiCuP shows better performances than NiCuO, which indicates that P is critical for the high activity of NiCuP. Based on several previous studies, the following roles of P are proposed. First, metal phosphides in NiCuP can serve as fast electron conductive channels because metal phosphides are much more conductive than metal oxides (i.e., 10 4 s/cm of Ni2P vs. 10 -10 S/cm for NiO) 61, 62 . Second, during the formation of metal phosphides, abundant oxygen vacancies are created in the Prich layer, which enhance the ion transfer. 39 Third, potential synergistic effects may exist between metal phosphides and oxides/hydroxides, which further improve the OER performances of NiCuP. 19
The catalytic performance results given above show that NiCuP is highly active for both HER and OER. The subsequent task is to match the cathodic and anodic reaction rates using this bifunctional catalyst to assemble a full water electrolyser unit. 35 The performances of NiCuP as a bifunctional catalyst for both HER and OER is first tested by cyclic voltammetry (CV) in a three-electrode configuration using Pt gauze as counter electrode. For performance comparison, Pt/C and IrO2 and a stainless steel foil without catalysts were also studied. Figure 4a shows that Pt/C has poor activity for OER, and IrO2 has negligible activity for HER. In contrast, NiCuP is highly active for both HER and OER. Next, the OER performances of different electrode couples as working and counter electrodes are further compared in 1 M KOH electrolyte with an Ag/AgCl reference electrode. Figure 4b illustrates the linearly fitted slopes of Tafel plots for several electrode couples: NiCuP//NiCuP, Pt/C//Pt/C, IrO2//IrO2 and IrO2//Pt/C (working electrode//counter electrode). The IrO2//Pt/C electrode couple shows the lowest onset overpotential. However, its Tafel slope (88 mV/dec) is larger than that of NiCuP//NiCuP at 76 mV/dec. Other electrode couples all display inferior performances (128 mV/dec for Pt/C//Pt/C and 227 mV/dec for IrO2//IrO2) due to their sluggish kinetics for either HER or OER.
Subsequently, a water electrolyser was assembled using two NiCuP deposited stainless steel electrodes in an H-shaped glass cell separated by a glass frit in 1 M KOH electrolyte. Water electrolysis in this water electrolyser was measured at 1.5 and 1.6 V, each for 10 h. As shown in Figure 4c, stable working currents of 4.2 and 20.8 mA/cm 2 can be maintained at both potentials throughout the test without iR-compensation. This performance is better than a number of recent total water splitting studies, including Co2B (10 mA/cm 2 @ 1.81V), 63 FeSx//FeOx (10 mA/cm 2 @ 2V in 0.1 M KOH), 64 NiCoO/NiCoS (5 mA/cm 2 @1.65V), 65 Co-P (4 mA/cm 2 @1.63V), 35 NiSe nanowire on Ni foam (10 mA/cm 2 @ 1.62 V @ 1.63 V), 18 NiFeCo LDH (10 mA/cm 2 @ 1.62 V) 22 and Co phosphide/phosphate film (10 mA/cm 2 @1.61V). 37 Table S3 in the ESI has listed a more detailed comparison with recently published results. The Faradic efficiency, which describes the efficiency of an electrochemical reaction in term of the usage of total charge transferred into an electrolysis system, can be estimated by
quantifying the H2 and O2 gas produced during the electrolysis. The gases produced from both chambers were quantified by a gas chromatograph (GC). A 2:1 molar ratio of H2 and O2 can be obtained throughout the process. Figure 4d shows that the amount of gases produced matches well with the theoretical calculated values, indicating a nearly 100% Faradic efficiency of the water electrolyser. Another advantage of the NiCuP electrode is its compacted structure with a small thickness of 0.13 mm, which allows us to stack multiple NiCuP electrodes together. Integrated electrodes of 1.1 mm in total thickness were fabricated by stacking five NiCuP electrodes using Parafilm as spacers (as shown in Figure S12 in ESI). A twoelectrode water electrolyser using such integrated electrode can reach a much larger working current density of 93.2 mA/cm 2 at 1.6 V, which is nearly 4 times higher than that of the water electrolyser using two single NiCuP electrodes. The large working current density is highly desirable for practical water electrolysis.
Figure 5. (a) Photograph of the water electrolyser assembled using NiCuP electrodes and powered by flexible Si solar cells. (b) The current response of the water electrolyser under a solar simulator and (c) recorded current and current retention of the water electrolyser under continuous illumination for 24 h.
To further demonstrate the potential for practical uses, commercially available flexible Si solar cells (~6% photoncurrent conversion efficiency) were used to power the water electrolyser as shown in Figure 5a. Assembled unit can continuously produce H2 and O2 under direct sunlight (see video S1 in ESI). Repeated on-off test was performed under a solar simulator to quantify its capability in total water splitting. Fast and steady responses upon switching illumination can be observed from its current profile in Figure 5b. A stable working current of 27.4 mA was obtained, and remained stable during a 24-h test (Figure 5c), which further confirms the stability of NiCuP. The photon energy to H2 conversion efficiency is about 4.2% due to the fact that the commercial solar cell has relatively low efficiency (see Figure S13 and discussion in ESI). 34 Using high efficiency solar cells could further improve the conversion efficiency from photon energy to H2 fuel.
Conclusions

sections.heading: ARTICLE Journal Name
sections.text:
6 | J. Name., 2012, 00, 1-3 This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
In conclusion, we demonstrated a bifunctional catalyst for water electrolysis with remarkable activity, strong robustness, and nearly 100% Faradaic efficiency. Hierarchically porous of NiCu nano-foams of 40 µm in thickness and 6.70 mg cm –2 were directly deposited on stainless steel foils. It shows promising HER and OER performances with overpotential of – 146 and 300 mV to reach the current density of 50 mA/cm 2 for HER and OER in 1 M KOH, respectively. These performances surpass those of commercial Pt/C and IrO2 catalysts. The bifunctional catalyst shows stable activity for at least 120 h under the current density of 50 mA/cm 2 . Ultrahigh current density up to 500 mA/cm 2 can be applied without blockage of electrode channels by gas bubbles or disintegration of catalysts from electrodes. A two-electrode water electrolyser was demonstrated with a molar ratio of 2:1 for the H2 and O2 produced from 1 M KOH. Additionally, the water electrolyser can also be powered by a commercial flexible Si solar cell (with a photon-current conversion efficiency of ~6%) to achieve ~4.2% photon energy to H2 conversion efficiency under a 24-h illumination test. Overall, we showed that the H2 bubble template electrodeposition is a facile, efficient and scalable approach to obtain porous foams with high surface area. Through this method, bimetallic foams with tunable morphology and elemental composition can be obtained in a few minutes, and their surfaces can be easily activated by different chemical methods, which allow them to not only serve as electrocatalysts for electrolysis of water, but also have broad potentials in other electrochemical applications, such as batteries or fuel cells.

sections.heading: Experimental
sections.text:
Preparation NiCuP electrodes. The H2 bubble templated electrodeposition of NiCu alloys was performed using an electrochemical workstation (Princeton, VERSAStat 3) in an acidic electrolyte, containing 0.5 M NiSO4, 0.01 M CuSO4 and 1.5 M H2SO4 (saturated with N2). Polished stainless steel (SS316) foils (0.5 cm in width, 0.05 mm in thickness) were used as deposition substrates and 1 cm was immerged in electrolytes. A Pt gauze and an Ag/AgCl (filled with saturated KCl solution) were used as counter and reference electrodes, respectively. The electrodeposition of NiCu alloys was carried out in an H-shaped two-chamber electrochemical cell separated by a fine glass frit (~4 mm in thickness) with Pt guaze electrode and the stainless steel foil in difference chambers to prevent Pt contamination from possible Pt stripping due to the high current density. Elemental analysis by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICPAES) showed no detectable Pt (detection limit at 0.1 ppm) in the deposited NiCu samples. The deposition current density was 1.8 A/cm 2 and the deposition time was 90 sec. After deposition, the electrode was thoroughly cleaned with DI water before a surface metal oxide layer was created by anodic passivation in 0.1 M NaOH solution at 1.3 V vs. RHE for 30 sec. Afterwards, the NiCu deposits were phosphidized to NiCuP catalysts using a low-temperature chemical vapor
deposition method in a two-temperature zone tube furnace. NaH2PO2 (Sigma-Aldrich, >99%) was used as a P precursor and loaded in a ceramic boat at a 200 °C zone, while NiCu foam was placed at a 300 °C zone about 10 cm apart from each other. The reaction was carried out for 1 hour, and then the samples were cooled to room temperature under flowing Ar. The areal weight loading of NiCuP on electrodes was ~6.70 mg/cm 2 determined by weighting the stainless steel foils before and before deposition. Two types of reference electrodes were also prepared by dispersing commercial Pt/C (20 wt.% Pt on Vulcan XC-72) and IrO2 (Sigma-Aldrich, 99.9%) catalysts on a hydrophilic carbon clothes (ELAT, NuVant, USA). Characterization. SEM and EDX characterization was carried out using a field emission SEM (JEOL, JSM-6700F). XRD patterns were recorded on an X-ray diffractometer (Bruker, AXS D8). XPS was performed on a XPS spectrometer (ThermoScientific, K-Alpha) equipped with an Al-Kα (1486.3 eV) radiation source. XPS depth profiles were collected with a 3 kV Ar+ ion beam bombardment on catalyst surfaces over an area of 2×2 µm 2 in total of 2000 sec, and a spectrum was collected every 20 sec. Electrochemical performance tests. Electrochemical tests were performed on an electrochemical workstation (CHI, 660E). All reported potentials were calibrated to a RHE. KOH electrolyte (1 M) was saturated with H2 (for HER) or O2 (for OER) before each test. The overhead space of the cell was covered with a PTFE cap and vented through a 1/8-inch port to maintain a nearly constant pressure (about 1 atm) during the tests. For tests using the three-electrode configuration, a Pt gauze electrode and a saturated Ag/AgCl electrode were used as counter electrode and reference electrode, respectively. LSV and CV tests were recorded at the scan rate of 5 mV/s. LSV was tested with 95% iR-compensation. Tafel slopes were obtained at the scan rate of 0.2 mV/s. During tests, gas bubbles can continuously dissipate to the electrolyte without stirring. The NiCuP electrode can work steadily at the current density as high as 500~600 mA/cm 2 . However, perturbations in the recorded current were observed at ~300 mA/cm 2 for Pt/C and 400 mA/cm 2 for IrO2 electrodes, respectively. An H-shaped electrochemical cell separated by a glass frit was used as a two-electrode water electrolyser. The overhead space above the electrolyte was kept around 20 mL. During the electrolysis of water, gas products were collected every 30 min and analyzed using a GC (Agilent, 6890N). Solar energy powered water electrolyser. Two pieces of commercial flexible Si solar panels (1.8 V open circuit potential (Voc), 6 % photoconversion efficiency, ~25 cm 2 total illuminated area) connected in series were used to power the H-shaped water electrolyser. Controlled experiments were carried out using a solar simulator (AM 1.5G filter and 150 W xenon lamp with power output of ~50 mW/cm 2 ). A shutter was used to control the light delivery to the solar panel. The potential and current were measured using a CHI 660E electrochemical workstation. The photon energy conversion efficiency was calculated according to a previously reported method. 34
